fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let {\mathopen {}\left (V,I,\otimes ,\alpha ,\lambda ,\rho \right )\mathclose {}} be a monoidal category. A category C enriched in V is defined by the following structure and axioms:

html:ol.html:li: for any two objects x,y, an object \mathbf {hom}_{C}{\mathopen {}\left (x,y\right )\mathclose {}}\in V;
for every object x, a morphism I\xrightarrow {i_{x}}\mathbf {hom}_{C}{\mathopen {}\left (x,x\right )\mathclose {}} in V;

for all objects x,y,z, a morphism \mathbf {hom}_{C}{\mathopen {}\left (x,y\right )\mathclose {}}\otimes \mathbf {hom}_{C}{\mathopen {}\left (y,z\right )\mathclose {}}\xrightarrow {c_{x,y,z}}\mathbf {hom}_{C}{\mathopen {}\left (x,z\right )\mathclose {}} in V.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: There is a common thread in modern approaches to domain theory, theory of computation, and topology: one has an object \Sigma with two points \bot ,\top :\Sigma that behave like the Sierpiński space, and it induces a binary “order” relation on any other object by serving as an interval: in particular, for a space X and points x,y:X we may say that x\sqsubseteq y when there exists a mapping H\colon \Sigma \to X such that H\bot = x and H\top = y. This is called the path order.

In addition to the path order described above, the Sierpiński space has its own intrinsic order: for p,q:\Sigma we say that p\leq q when p=\top implies q=\top . The Phoa principle is an important law governing the Sierpiński space ensuring that the path order and the intrinsic order coincide.

The map \Sigma ^\Sigma \to \Sigma \times \Sigma sending f to the pair {\mathopen {}\left (f\bot ,f\top \right )\mathclose {}} is an embedding and its image is the subset of \Sigma \times \Sigma spanned by pairs {\mathopen {}\left (p,q\right )\mathclose {}} such that p=\top implies q=\top .

A concrete model of domain theory (like cpos) is always a poset-enriched category, which can also be thought of as a (locally posetal) 2-category. I have discovered that it is possible to re-formulate Phoa’s principle in terms of 2-categorical universal properties of comma and cocomma squares, and it can be shown that in a cartesian closed locally posetal 2-category, an appropriate version of Phoa’s principle always holds.

In fact, an appropriate version of Phoa’s principle should hold in any cartesian closed 2-category (including non-posetal ones), and the proposal is to prove that this is the case using string diagrams. This result will have implications for the understanding of higher-dimensional domain theory as applied to concurrency.

A category with zero morphisms is defined to be a category enriched in the category of pointed sets and strict maps. The distinguished point of \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {A}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}} shall be written 0.
A monoidal category is a category C equipped with the following structure and axioms:

html:ol.html:li: a functor C\times C\xrightarrow {\otimes }C called the tensor product;
an object I\in C called the tensor unit;
a natural isomorphism {\mathopen {}\left (x\otimes y\right )\mathclose {}}\otimes z \xrightarrow {\alpha _{x,y,z}} x\otimes {\mathopen {}\left (y\otimes z\right )\mathclose {}} called the associator;
a natural isomorphism I\otimes x \xrightarrow {\lambda _{x}}x called the left unitor;
a natural isomorphism x\otimes I \xrightarrow {\rho _{x}}x called the right unitor;
